w:r.w:t: The teacher will teach basic music vocabulary by using TPR, sentence frames, and vocabulary. Students will study these words and phrases: sounds, loud, quiet, drums, piano, triangle, harp, Is it loud or quiet, Yes a ________ is loud, Yes, a _______ is quiet, musical instruments
At completion of this lesson, students will be able to:
Recognize, spell, and pronounce the words for music
Spell and pronounce common associated words
Use sets of words in complete sentences
Word List: sounds, loud, quiet, drums, piano, triangle, harp
This slide will always be the Naativ-branded opener slide that the teacher will display as the student enters the classroom.
Greet your student and introduce the lesson concept: “Today, we are going to be learning about music!
Make the sound for popcorn – pop, pop, pop
Read the poem to the student.
Circle the “pop-pop-pop” part. Read this part again and have the child say it, too. Point to your ear and say, “pop-pop-pop,” like you are hearing popcorn pop.
Circle the picture and put your hand to your ear to show the action for
while pretending to say that really loud. Have the child repeat.
while saying that really quietly and put your finger to your mouth like the boy in the picture. Have the child repeat.
A baby is loud, Fireworks are loud, Drums are loud

Circle the baby and ask,”Is a crying baby LOUD?” Make the action for LOUD when you ask. Say, “Yes, a crying baby is loud.” Have the child repeat (with the action). Ask the question a second time for extra practice. Repeat with the fireworks and drums.
A cat is quiet, A whisper is quiet, A sleeping baby is quiet

Circle the cat and ask, ”Is a cat quiet?” Make the action for quiet when you ask. Say, “Yes, a cat is quiet.” Have the child repeat (with the action). Ask the question a second time for extra practice. Repeat with the whisper picture and sleeping baby.
Answer, “Is it loud or quiet?” in complete phrases with actions.
Circle the first picture and ask, “Is a whisper quiet or loud?” (Do the actions for quiet and loud as you ask the question.) Encourage and prompt the child to answer in a complete phrase,
while doing the action for quiet.
while pretending to play a guitar and then a piano. Have the child repeat.
Circle the picture of the drums. Say,
and pretend to play the drums. Have the child repeat.
by pretending to hit a drum for each letter of the word. Encourage the child to spell the word in the same way.
Circle the picture of the piano. Say,
and pretend to play piano. Have the child repeat.
by pretending to play a piano key for each letter of the word. Encourage the child to spell the word in the same way.
Circle the picture of the triangle. Say,
and pretend to play a triangle like the lady in the picture. Have the child repeat.
by pretending to play a triangle and hitting the triangle each time you say a new letter. Encourage the child to spell the word in the same way.
Circle the picture of the harp. Say,
and pretend to play a harp. Have the child repeat.
Draw a line from the musical instrument to the name
Using the drawing tool on the screen, begin to draw a line from the picture of the harp to the word,
Encourage the child to finish independently.
Circle one picture at a time. Put your hand to your ear and encourage the child to say the name of the musical instrument.
Circle the correct picture as your teacher prompts
Circle one of the pictures and ask, “Is it quiet or loud.” The student should answer with the correct vocabulary word, quiet or loud.
Make some simple sounds (whisper, purr, read, hit the table, etc.). Ask the child if the sound is quiet or loud.
Tell if each instrument is quiet or loud
Circle the harp and ask, “Is this loud or quiet?” Encourage the child to answer in a complete sentence,
Tell what instruments you like in a complete sentence.

Ask, “What do you like?” (while giving a thumbs-up for the word like.) Give an example by pointing to yourself and saying, “I like the drums.” Ask the child again and encourage them to answer in a complete sentence.
and do the action shown in the picture.
Circle the picture of the ears and say,
. Have the child do the same.
Circle the picture of the boy and say,
Do the action the boy is doing and have the child do the same.
while doing the two actions. Have the child repeat.
Try to make a sentence with the pictures below
Encourage the child to make a sentence using the pictures. Circle one picture at a time. I hear loud and quiet sounds.
Freeform “Show and Tell” Conversation Activity Slide
Students should have a blank slide to draw a picture of
sounds, loud, quiet, drums, piano, triangle, harp
sounds, loud, quiet, drums, piano, triangle, harp)
Teacher will prompt student to draw a picture to represent
sounds, loud, quiet, drums, piano, triangle, harp
through pictures. One prompt at a time.
Teacher will write words from the lesson (
sounds, loud, quiet, drums, piano, triangle, harp)
Word Wall Vocabulary Builder Activity – Slide 22
Students will read and spell their new words:
sounds, loud, quiet, drums, piano, triangle, harp
Teacher will give feedback on the spelling and pronunciation of the new words.
